physicalObject: compact mechanical keyboard with dark gray keys and one orange keycap
proxyLocation: top right of the white tabletop
utilizationMethod: Hold the keyboard upright by gripping the narrow right-hand edge between thumb and fingers. The flat, rigid side surface gives a smooth plane that can be tapped against the table to imitate the fork’s tines striking a plate while still letting the wrist perform light stabbing or scooping motions.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This virtual fork would be used for dining activities
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: A fork is relatively lightweight but has some mass.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a flat and elongated shape with smooth, tapered edges - wider at the top and gradually narrowing toward the fork head (about 0.8-1 inch wide at its widest point, and roughly 2-3mm thick).
virtualObjectInfo.texture: User should feel the surface as smooth and polished like stainless steel.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user will pick up the fork by pinching or wrapping the thumb and first two fingers around the flat handle (precision-to-light power grip). Once grasped, the hand rotates the fork 90–180° at the wrist so the tines face downward or horizontally. Typical motions include short stabs into food, scooping gestures, and gentle wrist pronation/supination to turn or twirl food. The fork is light, so inertial feedback is minimal—a quick start-stop with little lag. The narrow handle edges and smooth stainless-steel surface give a cool, rigid feel with no deformation. When the tines strike a plate or food, the user would feel a brief tap or vibration through the handle, after which the fork remains rigid and immediately follows the hand’s next motion.

physicalObject: wooden hand broom with black bristles and a light wood handle
proxyLocation: center right of the white tabletop
utilizationMethod: Grip only the narrow wooden handle, letting the bristle head point forward. The slim, smooth wood approximates a flat utensil handle, while the light weight allows quick wrist rotations similar to turning a fork. Gentle taps with the bristle tips against the table simulate the soft contact of fork tines with food.

physicalObject: red-handled flat-head screwdriver with a metal shaft
proxyLocation: right side of the white tabletop
utilizationMethod: Pinch the metal shaft just below the plastic handle to feel a slender, cool, rigid surface close in width to a fork handle. Point the metal tip outward and perform short stabbing or scooping motions. Contact between the metal tip and table reproduces the brief tap sensation of fork tines hitting a plate.

physicalObject: compact mechanical keyboard with dark gray keys and one orange keycap
proxyLocation: top-right of the white table
utilizationMethod: Grip the keyboard on one of its short narrow edges with a pinch grip from thumb and fingers; the long, flat body then extends outward like a wide knife blade. Saw or press the long edge against the table surface to imitate the knife’s forward/back cutting strokes while the smooth keycaps provide a continuous, hard surface similar to stainless steel.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This virtual fork would be used for dining activities
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: A knife is relatively lightweight but has some mass.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a flat and elongated shape with smooth, tapered edges - wider at the top and gradually narrowing toward the fork head (about 0.8-1 inch wide at its widest point, and roughly 2-3mm thick).
virtualObjectInfo.texture: User should feel the surface as smooth and polished like stainless steel.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The knife is grasped with a hybrid precision/power grip: thumb and index finger pinch either side of the flat handle while the remaining fingers wrap for stability, and the index finger often extends along the spine for guidance. The user performs sawing or downward pressing strokes to cut, or smooth lateral strokes to spread. Each cut involves forearm-driven forward/back translations plus small wrist pivots that keep the blade angled against the food. Because the knife is light and rigid, it follows hand motion closely but gives momentary resistance when the virtual blade meets food—perceived as increased force or brief vibration. The stainless surface feels cool, smooth, and non-compliant throughout.

physicalObject: wooden hand broom with black bristles and a light wood handle
proxyLocation: center-right of the white table
utilizationMethod: Hold the flat wooden handle as the knife handle. The thin rectangular head and soft bristle face project outward like a blade. Perform wrist-driven sawing motions so the broom head leads the motion; the resistance of the bristles against the table provides a slight drag that mimics a knife edge meeting food.

Because the knife is light and rigid, it follows hand motion closely but gives momentary resistance when the virtual blade meets food—perceived as increased force or brief vibration. The stainless surface feels cool, smooth, and non-compliant throughout.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This virtual fork would be used for dining activities
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: A spoon is relatively lightweight but has some mass.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a flat and elongated shape with smooth, tapered edges - wider at the top and gradually narrowing toward the fork head (about 0.8-1 inch wide at its widest point, and roughly 2-3mm thick).
virtualObjectInfo.texture: User should feel the surface as smooth and polished like stainless steel.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The spoon is held much like the fork—thumb and index/middle fingers pinch the narrow handle while the other fingers cradle it (precision grip). The wrist then tilts to orient the bowl upward for scooping. Typical motions include forward scoops through semi-liquid food, lifting toward the mouth, and gentle rotations to pour contents. The bowl of the spoon adds slight front-heavy weight, so users notice a small inertial lag when starting or stopping motion compared with the handle alone. When fluid content is present, users feel extra mass and shifting momentum. The utensil remains rigid, with a smooth, cool surface and a shallow concave outline that presses against the finger pads.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This virtual pepper shaker would be used for seasoning food
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: The shaker should feel moderately weighted due to the pepper contents inside, with noticeable weight distribution that shifts dynamically as the pepper granules move during shaking.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Users should feel the fitted diameter when gripped
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The pepper shaker is grasped with the thumb, index, and middle fingers encircling the cylindrical body (light power grip). Users lift it a few centimeters above the plate and perform rapid wrist flicks—short, repetitive vertical or diagonal shakes—causing the internal granules to rattle. The shifting contents create a slightly delayed weight redistribution that can be felt as a soft inertial lag each time direction changes. The top surface occasionally taps the palm or fingers when inverted, and the user feels the cool, rigid glass/metal surface with shallow ridges where the cap meets the body. The object itself remains rigid, but the moving pepper produces subtle vibration and impact sounds that reinforce the seasoning action.

proxyLocation: center-right of the white table with bristles pointing left

The top surface occasionally taps the palm or fingers when inverted, and the user feels the cool, rigid glass/metal surface with shallow ridges where the cap meets the body. The object itself remains rigid, but the moving pepper produces subtle vibration and impact sounds that reinforce the seasoning action.
